elements.content: The modulating degree of defect and graphitization carbon coupled metal oxide composite is extremely important because these materials have been applied in various fatal fields, especially in energy storage/conversion and catalysis. Herein, we reported the in situ formation of long defect-rich nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes (NCNTs) coupled with a porous TiO2@NC composite (TiO2@NC–NCNTs) derived from spindle-type bimetallic (Ti/Co) MOF microrods. Thanks to the rational composition and unique structure, the as-prepared Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 can be used as a bifunctional fuel cell electrocatalyst. For MOR, the optimized catalyst exhibits superior mass activity of 577 mA mgPt –1 (in acidic medium) and 3100 mA mgPt –1 (in alkaline medium), which is 2.02 and 4.08 times superior than the commercial Pt/C catalyst, and shows excellent CO tolerance and better cyclic stability. This state-of-the-art nanocatalyst also exhibits a more positive onset potential (1.01 V) and upper limiting current density (5.03 mA cm–2) than commercial Pt/C (0.96 V and 4.75 mA cm–2) toward oxygen reduction reaction. The optimized degree of defect and graphitization in N-doped carbon (including NC and NCNTs) of the nanocatalyst not only provides large amounts of active sites to Pt NP deposition but also is positive for the charge transfer improvement of the overall nanocatalyst. The strong-coupled Pt–NCNTs­(NC)–TiO2 can further boost the catalytic activity and CO-tolerance. This work not only opens a new approach to develop a novel carbon/metal oxide composite with the desired morphology and properties but also provides new insights into the design and construction of state-of-the-art nanomaterials for fuel cells, water splitting, and photocatalysis.

elements.content:
A modulating defect and graphitization carbon coupled metal oxide composite is important to design and construct state-of-the-art nanomaterials for DFMC.

Introduction

Direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs) have received tremendous research interests and also been deemed a considerable project as a talented electrical energy for portable electronic equipment and electric vehicles because of their low operating temperature, high-energy density, supernal energy conversion efficiency, easy handling, and zero greenhouse gas emission. The fateful issues, including high cost, slow reaction kinetics, limited utilization, and easy poisoning by strongly intermediate species, is an indispensable portion for application of metal platinum (Pt) for either the cathodic oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) or anodic methanol oxidation reaction (MOR). Therefore, the strategies related to increasing the Pt utilization efficiency and reduce the active site of catalyst poisoning of Pt while promoting catalytic performance of DMFCs are extremely desired.

Introduction

Direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs) have received tremendous research interests and also been deemed a considerable project as a talented electrical energy for portable electronic equipment and electric vehicles because of their low operating temperature, high-energy density, supernal energy conversion efficiency, easy handling, and zero greenhouse gas emission. The fateful issues, including high cost, slow reaction kinetics, limited utilization, and easy poisoning by strongly intermediate species, is an indispensable portion for application of metal platinum (Pt) for either the cathodic oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) or anodic methanol oxidation reaction (MOR). Therefore, the strategies related to increasing the Pt utilization efficiency and reduce the active site of catalyst poisoning of Pt while promoting catalytic performance of DMFCs are extremely desired.

elements.content: In general, the design and construction of advanced materials containing Pt NPs can largely accelerate the MOR and ORR processes. The carbon-based support, such as carbon black, carbon nanotubes (CNTs), carbon nanofibers, and graphene, for Pt-based electrocatalysts have a large surface area and high electrical conductivity, which not only allocate a high-quality dispersion of metal loading but also accelerate electron transport during the electrochemical reaction. Typically, CNTs, especially N-doped CNTs (N-CNTs), have been deemed as a hot star support for DMFCs because of their unique cavities and one-dimensional electronic structures. The doping of nitrogen in CNTs considerably strengthen on the noble-metal–support interaction and hydrophilicity, which is benefited for Pt NP nucleation, growth, loading, and anchoring. However, N-CNTs coupled with Pt NPs are not robust enough, reflecting fast corrosion under harsh reaction conditions and strong poisoning of COads intermediate. Typically, metal oxides with favorable −OH adsorption forcefully transform COads to CO2 molecules to rejuvenate the real active sites of the Pt surface, indirectly mitigating poisoning of Pt NPs. Furthermore, the strong force between Pt NPs and metal oxide make the states of the d-band in Pt decrease, also leading to the weakening of interaction between Pt and COads. Among these metal oxides, rutile titanium dioxide (TiO2), owing to natural abundance, nontoxicity, high corrosion resistance, and chemical resistance in both the acid medium and alkaline electrolyte, has attracted attention but is hindered by its low electric conductivity. Accordingly, the N-CNTs/TiO2 support, a type of metal oxide–carbon materials, possessed considerable electron conductivity, better corrosion resistance, and quickly CO stripping, have been stared as a promise candidate for DMFCs. Recently, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with a large specific surface area, tunable pore structures, and inherently high porosity have emerged as the perfect platform for the in situ synthesis of nanocarbon coupled with metal oxide composites. The in situ carbon coupled with metal oxides not only maintain good conductivity and greatly shorten the diffusion length to an electrode but also greatly boost ion accessibility and accelerate electron transport.

elements.content: Based on above considerations, we reported the in situ formation of long defect-rich nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes (NCNTs) coupled with porous TiO2/NC composite (TiO2@NC–NCNTs) derived from spindle-type bimetallic (Ti/Co) MOF microrods (). An interesting phenomenon that the defects and graphitization degree can be skillfully optimized by tuning the ratio of Ti and Co in the MOF precursor is found. Carbon specimen, including NCNTs and N-doped carbon, prove large surface area sites for Pt deposition and also accelerate electron transfer in the electrochemical reaction. The abundant defect site can serve as Pt nanocluster nucleate site, which is further help Pt NP dispersions, growth, and Ostwald ripening and also expected to act as an effective trap to improve the stability of anchoring Pt NPs on the support during MOR and ORR. The challenge that the controllable balance of defect and graphitization degree in advanced materials is ingeniously solved in this work. The optimal defect and graphitization degree support [(TiO2)7–Co3@NC–NCNTs] with Pt NP loading as a bifunctional catalyst toward MOR and ORR exhibit remarkable catalytic activity, great CO tolerance, and stability in both acid and alkaline media. For MOR, the mass activities of Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 are about 577and 3100 mA mgPt –1 in H2SO4 and KOH, respectively, which are 2.02 and 4.08 times than those of commercial Pt/C. This state-of-the-art nanocatalyst also exhibits a more positive onset potential (1.01 V) and upper limiting current density (5.03 mA cm–2) than Pt/C (0.96 V and 4.75 mA cm–2) toward ORR. The optimized degree of defect and graphitization in N-doped carbon (including NC and NCNTs) of the nanocatalyst not only provide large amounts of active sites for Pt NP deposition but also is positive for the charge transfer improvement of the overall nanocatalyst. The strong-coupled Pt–NCNTs­(NC)–TiO2 further boost the catalytic activity and CO-tolerance. This work not only opens a new approach to develop the novel carbon/metal oxide composite with the desired morphology and properties but also provide a new insight viewpoint for design and construction of the electrocatalyst for fuel cell and water splitting.

elements.content: Schematic process used to construct Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs.
elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic process used to construct Pt/TiO2@NC-NCNTs.

elements.content: Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs catalysts were prepared as schematically illustrated in . Titanium isopropoxide and terephthalic acid were dissolved in dimethylformamide and Co­(Ac)2 was dissolved in methanol, respectively. After the mixed solution heated at 150 °C for 24 h, the obtained materials were ground with melamine and calcined in the nitrogen (N2) atmosphere. Finally, Pt nanoparticle deposition procession occurs in hexachloroplatinic acid dissolved in ethylene glycol with the assist microwave reaction (Experimental Section). The −OH groups of ethylene glycol are oxidized to aldehydes. These aldehydes are not very stable and are easily oxidized to glycolic and oxalic acid. The electrons provided by these oxidation reactions lead to the reduction of the Pt metal ions. The final catalysts were named Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-X because Co dissolved in strong acidic conditions. For better comparison, a series of catalyst supports with tuning molar ratios of Ti and Co was synthesized.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Pt/TiO2@NC-NCNTs catalysts were prepared as schematically illustrated in . Titanium isopropoxide and terephthalic acid were dissolved in dimethylformamide and Co(Ac)2 was dissolved in methanol, respectively. After the mixed solution heated at 150 °C for 24 h, the obtained materials were ground with melamine and calcined in the nitrogen (N2) atmosphere. Finally, Pt nanoparticle deposition procession occurs in hexachloroplatinic acid dissolved in ethylene glycol with the assist microwave reaction (Experimental Section). The -OH groups of ethylene glycol are oxidized to aldehydes. These aldehydes are not very stable and are easily oxidized to glycolic and oxalic acid. The electrons provided by these oxidation reactions lead to the reduction of the Pt metal ions. The final catalysts were named Pt/TiO2@NC-NCNTs-X because Co dissolved in strong acidic conditions. For better comparison, a series of catalyst supports with tuning molar ratios of Ti and Co was synthesized.

elements.content: The crystalline structure of TiO2@NC and (TiO2) x –Co y @NC–NCNTs are revealed by X-ray diffraction (XRD) analyses (a). All sharp distinct diffraction peaks of TiO2@NC at 2θ = 27.4, 36.1, 54.3, and 69.0° can be unquestionably indexed to rutile TiO2 (PDF# 21-1276), corresponding to the (110), (101), (211), and (301) planes of rutile TiO2. It can been seen that the XRD patterns of (TiO2) x –Co y @NC–NCNTs match well with rutile TiO2 (PDF# 21-1276) and metallic Co (PDF# 15-0806). The diffraction peaks located at ∼44.2, ∼51.5, and ∼75.8° relate to the (111), (200), and (220) planes of metallic Co. High crystallinity samples are all retained carbon species, but diffraction peaks for TiO2@NC and (TiO2)9–Co1@NC–NCNTs at 26° are indistinguishable. This diffraction peak appeared and goes sharply increases with the addition of cobalt acetate, indicating that the cobalt species plays an important role in carbon fixation on TiO2. As shown in Figure S1, we found that the diffraction peak of cobalt disappeared in the catalyst and can hardly see the diffraction peak of Pt, caused by the very strong diffraction peak of TiO2. This phenomenon can be better explained and proved by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). As shown in b, the shape of TiO2@NC and (TiO2) x –Co y @NC–NCNTs composites in the air atmosphere are similar and all exhibit a major weight loss in the temperature range from ∼350 to ∼600 °C, corresponding to the combustion of carbon. The content of carbon in TiO2@NC, (TiO2)9–Co1@NC–NCNTs, (TiO2)7–Co3@NC–NCNTs, and (TiO2)5–Co5@NC–NCNTs are calculated to be 9.2, 14.8, 42.4, and 50.5%, respectively, from the analysis of TGA results. Raman spectroscopy characteristic signatures of TiO2@NC and (TiO2) x –Co y @NC–NCNTs were shown in c, which are described by renowned D and G bands emerging at ∼1350 and 1590 cm–1, respectively. Generally, the intensity of the D band can be assigned to the disordered defective in graphite, while the intensity of the G band is related to the ordered crystal graphite. The D/G intensity ratio (I D/I G) value of TiO2@NC, (TiO2)9–Co1@NC–NCNTs, (TiO2)7–Co3@NC–NCNTs, and (TiO2)5–Co5@NC–NCNTs are 1.14, 1.33, 1.29, and 1.24, respectively. In addition, a broad 2D and 2G band centered at around 2660 and 2900 cm–1 are obviously observed in Raman spectra of TiO2@NC and (TiO2) x –Co y @NC–NCNTs, indicating the existence of graphitic carbon materials in all samples, and intensity of these two peaks gradually become stronger and more distinct with the increase of Co content in the MOF precursor. Typical Raman bands appeared at 140, 251, 426, and 610 cm–1 ascribe to the B1g, two-phonon scattering, Eg, and A1g modes of the rutile phase, respectively (Figure S2) and the peaks detected at about 187, 465, and 667 cm–1 correspond to F2g, Eg, and A1g modes of Co3O4, respectively. Raman reflects the vibration behavior of molecular bonds. Metal, as an elementary substance, has no molecular bonds. Therefore, there are weak diffraction peaks of Co3O4 but no diffraction peak of the Co metal in Figure S2. Based on the above results, metallic cobalt under high-temperature reduction can act as the catalytic center to produce more content of graphic carbon, improvement of overall electroconductibility of materials, while it can also introduce more amount of defect in carbon, leading to smaller Pt NPs as well as strengthening the interaction between carbon and metal NPs. (TiO2)7–Co3@NC–NCNTs was artfully endowed with both a high degree of carbon crystallinity and abundant defect edge.

elements.content: Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy was operated to disclose the different chemical bond in MIL–Ti and MIL–Ti x Co y (d). The band at about 1700 cm–1 is most likely attributed to asymmetric vibrations of carboxylate groups. The strong bands at ∼1400 and ∼1600 cm–1 can be assigned to the vibrational stretching of carboxylic acids (O–C–O), and peaks located at 1280 and 1149 cm–1 can be attributed to the vibrations of C–O. The intensity of CO bonds considerably weaken while that of C–O bonds remarkably increase with continuous enhancement of cobalt content, which shows that more C–O bonds are derived from the CO bond. The obvious O–Ti–O vibrations can be clearly observed at ∼800 cm–1. Figure S3 shows the nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherm and pore size distribution of the final products. All curves show typical IV-type isotherms with H3-type hysteresis loops. Remarkably, the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) specific surface area of TiO2@NC, (TiO2)9–Co1@NC–NCNTs, (TiO2)7–Co3@NC–NCNTs, and (TiO2)5–Co5@NC–NCNTs are 226.3, 90.4, 181, and 186.6 m2 g–1, respectively. The value of the BET specific surface area becomes more and more larger with increasing the content of cobalt in the MOFs, confirming the fact that carbon improves the specific surface area of the whole electrocatalyst. Mesopores mainly below 4 nm overall exist in the final products, which help reduce local electrical resistance and dielectric constant, increasing the electrical conductivity of the materials.

elements.content: The morphological analysis of MIL–Ti7Co3 and (TiO2)7–Co3@NC–NCNTs is carried out by using a field-emission electron microscope, as respectively shown in . The low-resolution FESEM image of MIL–Ti7Co3 (a) reveals that the lengths of spindle-type microrods are roughly 3.3 μm with a diameter of ca. 0.9–1.1 μm. On close inspection, the surface of spindle rods is rough and clearly observed many spileholes (b), benefiting from the natural advantage of MOFs. The element mapping analysis identify that MIL–Ti7Co3 consisted of elemental C, O, Co, and Ti components (c), and these four elements are distributed homogeneously throughout the whole spindle-type microrods, which further verify the carboxyl in TA incorporating both Ti4+ and Co2+ (d). In addition, the morphology of precursors exhibtis spindle-type microrods with the appearance of the cobalt specimen and the ratio of length and diameter of spindle-type microrods become bigger, from 2.91 to 3.30, with the increasing content of cobalt in MOFs (b and S4). d,e clearly demonstrates that the high density of long length N-CNTs with random orientations twine around and in situ grew on the (TiO2)7–Co3@NC–NCNTs surface. During the pyrolysis process, in situ Co metal reduced by high-temperature catalyzes the abundant organic residuals thermal decomposition from melamine to grow N-CNTs from the inside to outside of the spindle-type microrods. As shown in f, C, O, and N element mainly distribute both on spindle-type microrods and N-CNTs, elemental Ti mostly allocate on spindle-type microrods, and elemental Co distribute whole EDX image. The above results indicate that Co metal is mainly retained in the cusp of CNTs, the CNTs are doped by the N element from melamine, and the C element of spindle-type microrods mainly originates from the pyrolysis of terephthalic acid.

elements.content: To further investigate detailed structure of support and observe the size distribution of Pt NPs on nanomaterials, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of (TiO2)7–Co3@NC–NCNTs (a–f) and Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 (g–l) are provided. The as-prepared (TiO2)7–Co3@NC–NCNTs consists of spindle-like parts and NCNTs fractions (a). The spindle-like host consisted of plentiful long-length NCNTs with high density and these NCNTs assemble toward the center of spindle-like hosts. b,c exhibits high-magnification TEM images of the individual spindle-like host, which reveal that the TiO2 NPs are also encapsulated by a few-layered carbon shells with approximately 4.4 nm. Precise interplanar spacings are verified to be 0.203 nm, corresponding to the (210) crystal plane of the rutile TiO2 NPs (c). d–f shows high-magnification TEM images of individual NCNTs, which clearly disclose that the outer and inner diameter of N-CNTs are 25 and 10 nm, respectively, with a multiwall thickness of 7.5 nm. Obviously, the crystal fringes with arrows indicated along the curled edge are not continuous, owing to the existence of defects, while the (002) crystal plane of graphic carbon are observed (f). For Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7, well dispersions of Pt NPs were deposited on both the surface of the spindle-type host and long-length defect NCNTs (g,j). The high-magnification TEM image of the individual spindle-like host in Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 (h) distinctly reveals that Pt NPs anchor on the NC coupled with TiO2 NPs to form a triple boundary, which assists in accelerating the charge transport during the electrochemical process. Interplanar spacings with 0.226 nm ascribe to the (111) crystal plane of Pt NPs (i). The high-angle annular dark-field imaging-scanning TEM image of Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 catalysts and the corresponding EDS elemental mapping shows the homogeneous distribution of C, N, O, Ti, and Pt elements in the whole nanostructure (Figure S6). j–l reveals that the average size of the Pt nanocluster is estimated to be ∼1.97 nm with a narrow distribution, and Pt nanoclusters prefer land on the defect site. These abundant point defects and step edges on NCNTs can serve as Pt nanocluster nucleate site, which is further helped by Pt NP dispersions, growth, and olstwald ripening. Such a defect is also further expected to act as an effective trap to improve the stability of anchoring Pt NPs on the support during MOR and ORR.

elements.content: X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was employed to analyze the species and chemical states of the nanocatalyst and electronic properties between Pt NPs and support. The full scale of XPS spectra indicate that C, N, O, Ti, and Pt elements exist in all catalysts (Figure S7). The Pt 4f core level XPS spectra of the Pt/TiO2@NC, Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-9, Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7, and Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-5 mainly exhibit two peaks, which are assigned to Pt 4f5/2 and Pt 4f7/2, respectively (a). In contrast to Pt/TiO2@NC, the Pt 4f peaks of the other three electrocatalysts expressively negative shift, ascribing to the electronic interaction between defects on NCNTs (NC) and Pt NPs. The negative shift of binding energy of the Pt 4f means that the Pt NPs can get electrons from the support, leading to a decrease in the d-band vacancy of Pt, according to the d-band center theory, the CO adsorption would be weakened as the d-band center decreases. Thus, the negative shift is facilitating the removal of the adsorbed poisoning intermediates such as COads for MOR. Obviously, the Pt 4f peaks of Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 and Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-5 were shifted positively compared with that of Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-9, which can be attributed to the decreasing size of Pt NPs on the support. Owing to the fact that Pt0 in the nanocatalyst plays a fatal role in catalytic process, the concentration ratio between the metallic platinum (Pt0) and divalent platinum (Pt2+) are thoroughly considered and evaluated by the corresponding two sets of Pt 4f deconvolution. The percentage of metallic platinum (Pt0) in Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 is 76%, presenting the highest level of Pt0 in the nanocatalyst (68% for Pt/TiO2@NC, 70% for Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-9, 72% for Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-5). The higher content of Pt0 in the nanocatalyst usually represent higher catalytic performance. The high-resolution N 1s XPS spectrum of Pt/TiO2@NC and Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-X (b) can be divided into three peaks, which are corresponding to the representative peaks of pyridinic N (398.1 eV), pyrrolic N (399.5 eV), and graphitic N (401.1 eV). The excellent catalytic activities are mainly attributed to electroneutrality break and electron transfer induced by N doping (especially pyridinic-N), which alter the charge and spin distribution in the carbon materials. Compared with Pt/TiO2@NC, the negative shift of pyridinic N in Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-9, Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7, and Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-5 is attributed to strong metal–support interaction and electron transfer. The pyridinic-N species considered the effective active sites of Pt/TiO2@NC, Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-9, Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7, and Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-5 are 38.44, 39.17, 48.64, and 45.81%, respectively, which can facilitate the electron transfer and decrease the overpotential for MOR and ORR. The two peaks located at 464.5 and 458.8 eV in Ti 2p XPS spectra (c) can be associated to the Ti 2p1/2 and Ti 2p3/2 spectra of the Ti4+ oxidation state in TiO2 and a negative shift of Ti 2p ascribe that Ti4+ is partially reduced into Ti3+. The deconvoluted XPS spectra for O 1s (Figure S5) display three types of oxygen species, corresponding to Ti–O–Ti, Ti–OH, and adsorb water molecules. As shown in d, the high-resolution C 1s spectra can be decomposed into four peaks centered at 284.6 eV (sp2–sp2 C), 285.5 eV (N–sp2 C), 286.2 eV (N–sp3 C), and 288.6 eV (π–π*).

elements.content: a,b shows the cyclic voltammograms (CVs) of prepared nanocatalysts and commercial Pt/C in N2-saturated acid (0.5 M H2SO4) and alkali medium (1 M KOH), respectively. The electrochemical surface area (ECSA) of the catalysts can be calculated on the basis of the hydrogen desorption region, which observed the potential windows from −0.2 to 0.1 V [vs saturated calomel electrode (SCE), 0.5 M H2SO4] and that from −0.85 to −0.5 V (vs Hg/HgO, 1 M KOH), respectively. The calculated ECSAs of Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 are 82.6 and 45.9 m2 g–1 in acid and alkali media, respectively, which are larger than that of Pt/TiO2@NC, Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-9, Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-5, and commercial Pt/C catalysts (c). The larger ECSA means that the Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 has more active sites in the electrocatalytic process. Meanwhile, the small size and uniform dispersion of Pt NPs on the support ascribes to a large ECSA, avoiding agglomeration of Pt NPs. The electrocatalytic properties of MOR were investigated in 0.5 M H2SO4 containing 1 M CH3OH and 1 M KOH containing 1 M CH3OH, respectively, and the current density is normalized by the current per content of Pt NP deposition (d,e). Among all the electrocatalysts, the MOR demonstrate that the forward scan of the Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 catalyst exhibits the highest mass current density of 577 mA mgPt –1 in acid and 3100 mA mgPt –1 in alkali, which is 2.02 times and 4.08 times that of commercial Pt/C. It can be also seen from f that the Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 catalyst has both superior mass activity and high ECSA-normalized specific activity in acidic and alkaline media, which is significantly better than the reported catalysts. In addition, compared to other four nanocatalysts, the onset potential of the forward anodic peak in Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 is more negative (g,h), implying fastest catalytic kinetics for methanol oxidation (i). Another problem restricting the development of MOR electrocatalysts is their poor operation durability. To further explore the above issue, chronoamperometric responses and continuous CVs of electrocatalysts were measured and are shown in Figures S8 and S9. Notably, the Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 shows the slowest deterioration rate and highest steady-state current among four nanocatalysts, further revealing that the novel Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 support boosts the catalytic ability along with reducing the poisonous effect of Pt NPs during MOR. After continuous 1000 CV cycling, Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 also exhibits the highest retention rate of that of the initial ECSA among all the electro-nanocatalysts. All of these consequences provide distinct evidence of the outstanding electrocatalytic activity and excellent catalytic stability of the Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 catalyst for MOR.

elements.content: Quick poisoning by COads adsorption leads to Pt NPs effortlessly losing a large amount of activity during methanol electro-oxidation. To further reveal the activity and durability enhancement mechanism, the COads stripping measurement are conducted in 0.5 M H2SO4 and 1 M KOH. In acid medium­(a), the onset potential of Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 (0.549 V vs SCE) is more negative than that of Pt/TiO2@NC (0.574 V vs SCE), Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-9 (0.556 V vs SCE), Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-5 (0.561 V vs SCE), and commercial Pt/C (0.700 V vs SCE), exhibiting better CO oxidation reactivity. In alkali medium (b), the onset electrooxidation potential of CO for Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 is also more negative (−0.518 V vs Hg/HgO) than other catalysts. It is demonstrated that the Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 facilitate the removal of COads species from the surface of the nanocatalyst and has the famous capability of antipoisoning, which is attributed to stronger OH– adsorption on the Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 support. Notably, Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-9, Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7, and Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-5 catalysts emerge a new broad peak at a more negative potential of −0.47 to −0.37 V, implying the presence of different active sites with diverse CO adsorption energy. Water is easy to be polarized by the Ti–O bond in TiO2 to form the abundant hydroxyl group, which can assist oxidization and detach adjacent COads species from the Pt NPs. The main process can be described by the below five reaction equations Ti O 2 + H 2 O → Ti O 2 − OH + H + + e − Pt + C H 3 OH → Pt − C O ads + 4 H + + 4 e − Ti O 2 − OH + Pt − C O ads → C O 2 + Pt + Ti O 2 + H + + e − Pt + H 2 O → Pt − OH + H + + e − Pt − C O ads + Pt − OH → 2 Pt + C O 2 + H + + e −

elements.content: Owing to the superior ECSA, high self-stability, outstanding electrocatalytic performance, and excellent CO antipoisoning performance, the Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 is more competitive than those of recent Pt-based electrocatalysts both in acid and alkaline media (Table S1). The diameter of the semicircle in the plot of the prepared Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 catalyst (Figure S10) is much smaller than that of the other catalysts, indicating a much suited interfacial resistance and electron/charge transfer resistance.
elements.clean_text: Owing to the superior ECSA, high self-stability, outstanding electrocatalytic performance, and excellent CO antipoisoning performance, the Pt/TiO2@NC-NCNTs-7 is more competitive than those of recent Pt-based electrocatalysts both in acid and alkaline media (Table S1). The diameter of the semicircle in the plot of the prepared Pt/TiO2@NC-NCNTs-7 catalyst (Figure S10) is much smaller than that of the other catalysts, indicating a much suited interfacial resistance and electron/charge transfer resistance.

elements.content: The ORR activity of the Pt/TiO2@NC-NCNTs-7 catalyst is evaluated through cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurement. A sharp cathodic peak centered at ∼0.86 V can be obviously noticed with the electrolyte saturated with O2 (a) and its location is more positive than that of commercial Pt/C (0.80 V, Figure S11), which clearly demonstrates that the ORR catalytic activity of Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 is more outstanding than Pt/C. Furthermore, Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 exhibits onset potential E onset (1.01 V) and half-wave potential E 1/2 (0.86 V, b), which are much more positive than that of commercial Pt/C (E onset = 0.96 V and E 1/2 = 0.82 V). The reaction kinetics of ORR are analyzed by Tafel plots (c). The Tafel slope of Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 (70 mV dec–1) is much smaller than that of Pt/C (77 mV dec–1), further confirming the unique (TiO2)7–Co3@NC–NCNTs support in promoting the reaction kinetics of Pt. LSV curves of Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 (d) are also collected by the rotating disk electrode setup from 400 to 2500 rpm and its corresponding Koutecky–Levich (K–L) plots are represented in e. The calculated K–L plots show nearly parallel fitting lines, indicating first-order reaction kinetics associated with the O2 concentration and a potential-independent electron transfer rate. The stability of the Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 was measured from the LSV curves initially and after 5000 cycles (f). The decrease in half-wave potential is only 4 mV signifying superior stability of the catalyst. The electrochemical tests clearly indicate that the Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 can be used as a superior bifunctional catalyst for both MOR and ORR. The extraordinary performance of the bifunctional fuel cell electrocatalyst (Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7) can be reasonably understood by the following facts. (1) Proper introduction of Co in MOFs produces both more defects and high graphitization in N-doped carbon, which not only endows the nanocatalyst with an excellent charge/electron transport ability but also provides a large amount of active sites to Pt NP deposition, further improving stability and catalytic activity in the electrochemical process. (2) High corrosion resistance and rich hydroxyl groups enable TiO2 to avoid poisoning by CO intermediates and retain the structural integrity of the whole catalysts under harsh electrochemical conditions. In a word, the catalyst of Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 has moderate defect sites, the highest content of pyridinic-N and Pt0, so the Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 exhibits superior catalytic activity toward to MOR and ORR.

Furthermore, Pt/TiO2@NC-NCNTs-7 exhibits onset potential E onset (1.01 V) and half-wave potential E 1/2 (0.86 V, b), which are much more positive than that of commercial Pt/C (E onset = 0.96 V and E 1/2 = 0.82 V). The reaction kinetics of ORR are analyzed by Tafel plots (c). The Tafel slope of Pt/TiO2@NC-NCNTs-7 (70 mV dec-1) is much smaller than that of Pt/C (77 mV dec-1), further confirming the unique (TiO2)7-Co3@NC-NCNTs support in promoting the reaction kinetics of Pt. LSV curves of Pt/TiO2@NC-NCNTs-7 (d) are also collected by the rotating disk electrode setup from 400 to 2500 rpm and its corresponding Koutecky-Levich (K-L) plots are represented in e. The calculated K-L plots show nearly parallel fitting lines, indicating first-order reaction kinetics associated with the O2 concentration and a potential-independent electron transfer rate. The stability of the Pt/TiO2@NC-NCNTs-7 was measured from the LSV curves initially and after 5000 cycles (f). The decrease in half-wave potential is only 4 mV signifying superior stability of the catalyst. The electrochemical tests clearly indicate that the Pt/TiO2@NC-NCNTs-7 can be used as a superior bifunctional catalyst for both MOR and ORR. The extraordinary performance of the bifunctional fuel cell electrocatalyst (Pt/TiO2@NC-NCNTs-7) can be reasonably understood by the following facts. (1) Proper introduction of Co in MOFs produces both more defects and high graphitization in N-doped carbon, which not only endows the nanocatalyst with an excellent charge/electron transport ability but also provides a large amount of active sites to Pt NP deposition, further improving stability and catalytic activity in the electrochemical process. (2) High corrosion resistance and rich hydroxyl groups enable TiO2 to avoid poisoning by CO intermediates and retain the structural integrity of the whole catalysts under harsh electrochemical conditions. In a word, the catalyst of Pt/TiO2@NC-NCNTs-7 has moderate defect sites, the highest content of pyridinic-N and Pt0, so the Pt/TiO2@NC-NCNTs-7 exhibits superior catalytic activity toward to MOR and ORR.

Conclusions

In summary, we have successfully fabricated in situ formation of long defect-rich NCNTs coupled with the porous TiO2/NC composite (TiO2@NC-NCNTs) derived from spindle-type bimetallic (Ti/Co) MOF microrods. Thanks to their appropriate component and unique structure, the bi-functional Pt/TiO2@NC-NCNTs-7 exhibits superior catalytic activity toward MOR and ORR in acid and alkaline media with significant improvements in stability. Proper introduction of Co in MOFs produces both more defects and high graphitization in N-doped carbon, which not only endows the nanocatalyst excellent charge/electron transport ability but also provides a large amount of active sites to Pt NP deposition, further improving stability and catalytic activity in the electrochemical process. High corrosion resistance and rich hydroxyl groups enable TiO2 to avoid poisoning by CO intermediates and retain the structural integrity of the whole catalyst under harsh electrochemical conditions. This work not only opens a new approach in developing a novel carbon/metal oxide composite with the desired morphology and properties but also provide a new viewpoint for the design and construction of the electrocatalyst for the fuel cell and water splitting.

cln_elements.content:
The modulating degree of defect and graphitization carbon coupled metal oxide composite is extremely important because these materials have been applied in various fatal fields, especially in energy storage/conversion and catalysis. Herein, we reported the in situ formation of long defect-rich nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes (NCNTs) coupled with a porous TiO2@NC composite (TiO2@NC–NCNTs) derived from spindle-type bimetallic (Ti/Co) MOF microrods. Thanks to the rational composition and unique structure, the as-prepared Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 can be used as a bifunctional fuel cell electrocatalyst. For MOR, the optimized catalyst exhibits superior mass activity of 577 mA mgPt –1 (in acidic medium) and 3100 mA mgPt –1 (in alkaline medium), which is 2.02 and 4.08 times superior than the commercial Pt/C catalyst, and shows excellent CO tolerance and better cyclic stability. This state-of-the-art nanocatalyst also exhibits a more positive onset potential (1.01 V) and upper limiting current density (5.03 mA cm–2) than commercial Pt/C (0.96 V and 4.75 mA cm–2) toward oxygen reduction reaction. The optimized degree of defect and graphitization in N-doped carbon (including NC and NCNTs) of the nanocatalyst not only provides large amounts of active sites to Pt NP deposition but also is positive for the charge transfer improvement of the overall nanocatalyst. The strong-coupled Pt–NCNTs­(NC)–TiO2 can further boost the catalytic activity and CO-tolerance. This work not only opens a new approach to develop a novel carbon/metal oxide composite with the desired morphology and properties but also provides new insights into the design and construction of state-of-the-art nanomaterials for fuel cells, water splitting, and photocatalysis.

The crystalline structure of TiO2@NC and (TiO2) x –Co y @NC–NCNTs are revealed by X-ray diffraction (XRD) analyses (a). All sharp distinct diffraction peaks of TiO2@NC at 2θ = 27.4, 36.1, 54.3, and 69.0° can be unquestionably indexed to rutile TiO2 (PDF# 21-1276), corresponding to the (110), (101), (211), and (301) planes of rutile TiO2. It can been seen that the XRD patterns of (TiO2) x –Co y @NC–NCNTs match well with rutile TiO2 (PDF# 21-1276) and metallic Co (PDF# 15-0806). The diffraction peaks located at ∼44.2, ∼51.5, and ∼75.8° relate to the (111), (200), and (220) planes of metallic Co. High crystallinity samples are all retained carbon species, but diffraction peaks for TiO2@NC and (TiO2)9–Co1@NC–NCNTs at 26° are indistinguishable. This diffraction peak appeared and goes sharply increases with the addition of cobalt acetate, indicating that the cobalt species plays an important role in carbon fixation on TiO2. As shown in Figure S1, we found that the diffraction peak of cobalt disappeared in the catalyst and can hardly see the diffraction peak of Pt, caused by the very strong diffraction peak of TiO2. This phenomenon can be better explained and proved by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). As shown in b, the shape of TiO2@NC and (TiO2) x –Co y @NC–NCNTs composites in the air atmosphere are similar and all exhibit a major weight loss in the temperature range from ∼350 to ∼600 °C, corresponding to the combustion of carbon. The content of carbon in TiO2@NC, (TiO2)9–Co1@NC–NCNTs, (TiO2)7–Co3@NC–NCNTs, and (TiO2)5–Co5@NC–NCNTs are calculated to be 9.2, 14.8, 42.4, and 50.5%, respectively, from the analysis of TGA results. Raman spectroscopy characteristic signatures of TiO2@NC and (TiO2) x –Co y @NC–NCNTs were shown in c, which are described by renowned D and G bands emerging at ∼1350 and 1590 cm–1, respectively. Generally, the intensity of the D band can be assigned to the disordered defective in graphite, while the intensity of the G band is related to the ordered crystal graphite. The D/G intensity ratio (I D/I G) value of TiO2@NC, (TiO2)9–Co1@NC–NCNTs, (TiO2)7–Co3@NC–NCNTs, and (TiO2)5–Co5@NC–NCNTs are 1.14, 1.33, 1.29, and 1.24, respectively. In addition, a broad 2D and 2G band centered at around 2660 and 2900 cm–1 are obviously observed in Raman spectra of TiO2@NC and (TiO2) x –Co y @NC–NCNTs, indicating the existence of graphitic carbon materials in all samples, and intensity of these two peaks gradually become stronger and more distinct with the increase of Co content in the MOF precursor. Typical Raman bands appeared at 140, 251, 426, and 610 cm–1 ascribe to the B1g, two-phonon scattering, Eg, and A1g modes of the rutile phase, respectively (Figure S2) and the peaks detected at about 187, 465, and 667 cm–1 correspond to F2g, Eg, and A1g modes of Co3O4, respectively. Raman reflects the vibration behavior of molecular bonds. Metal, as an elementary substance, has no molecular bonds. Therefore, there are weak diffraction peaks of Co3O4 but no diffraction peak of the Co metal in Figure S2. Based on the above results, metallic cobalt under high-temperature reduction can act as the catalytic center to produce more content of graphic carbon, improvement of overall electroconductibility of materials, while it can also introduce more amount of defect in carbon, leading to smaller Pt NPs as well as strengthening the interaction between carbon and metal NPs. (TiO2)7–Co3@NC–NCNTs was artfully endowed with both a high degree of carbon crystallinity and abundant defect edge.

Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy was operated to disclose the different chemical bond in MIL–Ti and MIL–Ti x Co y (d). The band at about 1700 cm–1 is most likely attributed to asymmetric vibrations of carboxylate groups. The strong bands at ∼1400 and ∼1600 cm–1 can be assigned to the vibrational stretching of carboxylic acids (O–C–O), and peaks located at 1280 and 1149 cm–1 can be attributed to the vibrations of C–O. The intensity of CO bonds considerably weaken while that of C–O bonds remarkably increase with continuous enhancement of cobalt content, which shows that more C–O bonds are derived from the CO bond. The obvious O–Ti–O vibrations can be clearly observed at ∼800 cm–1. Figure S3 shows the nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherm and pore size distribution of the final products. All curves show typical IV-type isotherms with H3-type hysteresis loops. Remarkably, the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) specific surface area of TiO2@NC, (TiO2)9–Co1@NC–NCNTs, (TiO2)7–Co3@NC–NCNTs, and (TiO2)5–Co5@NC–NCNTs are 226.3, 90.4, 181, and 186.6 m2 g–1, respectively. The value of the BET specific surface area becomes more and more larger with increasing the content of cobalt in the MOFs, confirming the fact that carbon improves the specific surface area of the whole electrocatalyst. Mesopores mainly below 4 nm overall exist in the final products, which help reduce local electrical resistance and dielectric constant, increasing the electrical conductivity of the materials.

The morphological analysis of MIL–Ti7Co3 and (TiO2)7–Co3@NC–NCNTs is carried out by using a field-emission electron microscope, as respectively shown in . The low-resolution FESEM image of MIL–Ti7Co3 (a) reveals that the lengths of spindle-type microrods are roughly 3.3 μm with a diameter of ca. 0.9–1.1 μm. On close inspection, the surface of spindle rods is rough and clearly observed many spileholes (b), benefiting from the natural advantage of MOFs. The element mapping analysis identify that MIL–Ti7Co3 consisted of elemental C, O, Co, and Ti components (c), and these four elements are distributed homogeneously throughout the whole spindle-type microrods, which further verify the carboxyl in TA incorporating both Ti4+ and Co2+ (d). In addition, the morphology of precursors exhibtis spindle-type microrods with the appearance of the cobalt specimen and the ratio of length and diameter of spindle-type microrods become bigger, from 2.91 to 3.30, with the increasing content of cobalt in MOFs (b and S4). d,e clearly demonstrates that the high density of long length N-CNTs with random orientations twine around and in situ grew on the (TiO2)7–Co3@NC–NCNTs surface. During the pyrolysis process, in situ Co metal reduced by high-temperature catalyzes the abundant organic residuals thermal decomposition from melamine to grow N-CNTs from the inside to outside of the spindle-type microrods. As shown in f, C, O, and N element mainly distribute both on spindle-type microrods and N-CNTs, elemental Ti mostly allocate on spindle-type microrods, and elemental Co distribute whole EDX image. The above results indicate that Co metal is mainly retained in the cusp of CNTs, the CNTs are doped by the N element from melamine, and the C element of spindle-type microrods mainly originates from the pyrolysis of terephthalic acid.

cln_elements.content:
To further investigate detailed structure of support and observe the size distribution of Pt NPs on nanomaterials, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of (TiO2)7–Co3@NC–NCNTs (a–f) and Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 (g–l) are provided. The as-prepared (TiO2)7–Co3@NC–NCNTs consists of spindle-like parts and NCNTs fractions (a). The spindle-like host consisted of plentiful long-length NCNTs with high density and these NCNTs assemble toward the center of spindle-like hosts. b,c exhibits high-magnification TEM images of the individual spindle-like host, which reveal that the TiO2 NPs are also encapsulated by a few-layered carbon shells with approximately 4.4 nm. Precise interplanar spacings are verified to be 0.203 nm, corresponding to the (210) crystal plane of the rutile TiO2 NPs (c). d–f shows high-magnification TEM images of individual NCNTs, which clearly disclose that the outer and inner diameter of N-CNTs are 25 and 10 nm, respectively, with a multiwall thickness of 7.5 nm. Obviously, the crystal fringes with arrows indicated along the curled edge are not continuous, owing to the existence of defects, while the (002) crystal plane of graphic carbon are observed (f). For Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7, well dispersions of Pt NPs were deposited on both the surface of the spindle-type host and long-length defect NCNTs (g,j). The high-magnification TEM image of the individual spindle-like host in Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 (h) distinctly reveals that Pt NPs anchor on the NC coupled with TiO2 NPs to form a triple boundary, which assists in accelerating the charge transport during the electrochemical process. Interplanar spacings with 0.226 nm ascribe to the (111) crystal plane of Pt NPs (i). The high-angle annular dark-field imaging-scanning TEM image of Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 catalysts and the corresponding EDS elemental mapping shows the homogeneous distribution of C, N, O, Ti, and Pt elements in the whole nanostructure (Figure S6). j–l reveals that the average size of the Pt nanocluster is estimated to be ∼1.97 nm with a narrow distribution, and Pt nanoclusters prefer land on the defect site. These abundant point defects and step edges on NCNTs can serve as Pt nanocluster nucleate site, which is further helped by Pt NP dispersions, growth, and olstwald ripening. Such a defect is also further expected to act as an effective trap to improve the stability of anchoring Pt NPs on the support during MOR and ORR.

X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was employed to analyze the species and chemical states of the nanocatalyst and electronic properties between Pt NPs and support. The full scale of XPS spectra indicate that C, N, O, Ti, and Pt elements exist in all catalysts (Figure S7). The Pt 4f core level XPS spectra of the Pt/TiO2@NC, Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-9, Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7, and Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-5 mainly exhibit two peaks, which are assigned to Pt 4f5/2 and Pt 4f7/2, respectively (a). In contrast to Pt/TiO2@NC, the Pt 4f peaks of the other three electrocatalysts expressively negative shift, ascribing to the electronic interaction between defects on NCNTs (NC) and Pt NPs. The negative shift of binding energy of the Pt 4f means that the Pt NPs can get electrons from the support, leading to a decrease in the d-band vacancy of Pt, according to the d-band center theory, the CO adsorption would be weakened as the d-band center decreases. Thus, the negative shift is facilitating the removal of the adsorbed poisoning intermediates such as COads for MOR. Obviously, the Pt 4f peaks of Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 and Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-5 were shifted positively compared with that of Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-9, which can be attributed to the decreasing size of Pt NPs on the support. Owing to the fact that Pt0 in the nanocatalyst plays a fatal role in catalytic process, the concentration ratio between the metallic platinum (Pt0) and divalent platinum (Pt2+) are thoroughly considered and evaluated by the corresponding two sets of Pt 4f deconvolution. The percentage of metallic platinum (Pt0) in Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 is 76%, presenting the highest level of Pt0 in the nanocatalyst (68% for Pt/TiO2@NC, 70% for Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-9, 72% for Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-5). The higher content of Pt0 in the nanocatalyst usually represent higher catalytic performance. The high-resolution N 1s XPS spectrum of Pt/TiO2@NC and Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-X (b) can be divided into three peaks, which are corresponding to the representative peaks of pyridinic N (398.1 eV), pyrrolic N (399.5 eV), and graphitic N (401.1 eV). The excellent catalytic activities are mainly attributed to electroneutrality break and electron transfer induced by N doping (especially pyridinic-N), which alter the charge and spin distribution in the carbon materials. Compared with Pt/TiO2@NC, the negative shift of pyridinic N in Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-9, Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7, and Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-5 is attributed to strong metal–support interaction and electron transfer. The pyridinic-N species considered the effective active sites of Pt/TiO2@NC, Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-9, Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7, and Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-5 are 38.44, 39.17, 48.64, and 45.81%, respectively, which can facilitate the electron transfer and decrease the overpotential for MOR and ORR. The two peaks located at 464.5 and 458.8 eV in Ti 2p XPS spectra (c) can be associated to the Ti 2p1/2 and Ti 2p3/2 spectra of the Ti4+ oxidation state in TiO2 and a negative shift of Ti 2p ascribe that Ti4+ is partially reduced into Ti3+. The deconvoluted XPS spectra for O 1s (Figure S5) display three types of oxygen species, corresponding to Ti–O–Ti, Ti–OH, and adsorb water molecules. As shown in d, the high-resolution C 1s spectra can be decomposed into four peaks centered at 284.6 eV (sp2–sp2 C), 285.5 eV (N–sp2 C), 286.2 eV (N–sp3 C), and 288.6 eV (π–π*).

a,b shows the cyclic voltammograms (CVs) of prepared nanocatalysts and commercial Pt/C in N2-saturated acid (0.5 M H2SO4) and alkali medium (1 M KOH), respectively. The electrochemical surface area (ECSA) of the catalysts can be calculated on the basis of the hydrogen desorption region, which observed the potential windows from −0.2 to 0.1 V [vs saturated calomel electrode (SCE), 0.5 M H2SO4] and that from −0.85 to −0.5 V (vs Hg/HgO, 1 M KOH), respectively. The calculated ECSAs of Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 are 82.6 and 45.9 m2 g–1 in acid and alkali media, respectively, which are larger than that of Pt/TiO2@NC, Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-9, Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-5, and commercial Pt/C catalysts (c). The larger ECSA means that the Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 has more active sites in the electrocatalytic process. Meanwhile, the small size and uniform dispersion of Pt NPs on the support ascribes to a large ECSA, avoiding agglomeration of Pt NPs. The electrocatalytic properties of MOR were investigated in 0.5 M H2SO4 containing 1 M CH3OH and 1 M KOH containing 1 M CH3OH, respectively, and the current density is normalized by the current per content of Pt NP deposition (d,e). Among all the electrocatalysts, the MOR demonstrate that the forward scan of the Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 catalyst exhibits the highest mass current density of 577 mA mgPt –1 in acid and 3100 mA mgPt –1 in alkali, which is 2.02 times and 4.08 times that of commercial Pt/C. It can be also seen from f that the Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 catalyst has both superior mass activity and high ECSA-normalized specific activity in acidic and alkaline media, which is significantly better than the reported catalysts. In addition, compared to other four nanocatalysts, the onset potential of the forward anodic peak in Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 is more negative (g,h), implying fastest catalytic kinetics for methanol oxidation (i). Another problem restricting the development of MOR electrocatalysts is their poor operation durability. To further explore the above issue, chronoamperometric responses and continuous CVs of electrocatalysts were measured and are shown in Figures S8 and S9. Notably, the Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 shows the slowest deterioration rate and highest steady-state current among four nanocatalysts, further revealing that the novel Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 support boosts the catalytic ability along with reducing the poisonous effect of Pt NPs during MOR. After continuous 1000 CV cycling, Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 also exhibits the highest retention rate of that of the initial ECSA among all the electro-nanocatalysts. All of these consequences provide distinct evidence of the outstanding electrocatalytic activity and excellent catalytic stability of the Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 catalyst for MOR.

To further investigate detailed structure of support and observe the size distribution of Pt NPs on nanomaterials, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of (TiO2)7-Co3@NC-NCNTs (a-f) and Pt/TiO2@NC-NCNTs-7 (g-l) are provided. The as-prepared (TiO2)7-Co3@NC-NCNTs consists of spindle-like parts and NCNTs fractions (a). The spindle-like host consisted of plentiful long-length NCNTs with high density and these NCNTs assemble toward the center of spindle-like hosts. b,c exhibits high-magnification TEM images of the individual spindle-like host, which reveal that the TiO2 NPs are also encapsulated by a few-layered carbon shells with approximately 4.4 nm. Precise interplanar spacings are verified to be 0.203 nm, corresponding to the (210) crystal plane of the rutile TiO2 NPs (c). d-f shows high-magnification TEM images of individual NCNTs, which clearly disclose that the outer and inner diameter of N-CNTs are 25 and 10 nm, respectively, with a multiwall thickness of 7.5 nm. Obviously, the crystal fringes with arrows indicated along the curled edge are not continuous, owing to the existence of defects, while the (002) crystal plane of graphic carbon are observed (f). For Pt/TiO2@NC-NCNTs-7, well dispersions of Pt NPs were deposited on both the surface of the spindle-type host and long-length defect NCNTs (g,j). The high-magnification TEM image of the individual spindle-like host in Pt/TiO2@NC-NCNTs-7 (h) distinctly reveals that Pt NPs anchor on the NC coupled with TiO2 NPs to form a triple boundary, which assists in accelerating the charge transport during the electrochemical process. Interplanar spacings with 0.226 nm ascribe to the (111) crystal plane of Pt NPs (i). The high-angle annular dark-field imaging-scanning TEM image of Pt/TiO2@NC-NCNTs-7 catalysts and the corresponding EDS elemental mapping shows the homogeneous distribution of C, N, O, Ti, and Pt elements in the whole nanostructure (Figure S6). j-l reveals that the average size of the Pt nanocluster is estimated to be ~1.97 nm with a narrow distribution, and Pt nanoclusters prefer land on the defect site. These abundant point defects and step edges on NCNTs can serve as Pt nanocluster nucleate site, which is further helped by Pt NP dispersions, growth, and olstwald ripening. Such a defect is also further expected to act as an effective trap to improve the stability of anchoring Pt NPs on the support during MOR and ORR. 

X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was employed to analyze the species and chemical states of the nanocatalyst and electronic properties between Pt NPs and support. The full scale of XPS spectra indicate that C, N, O, Ti, and Pt elements exist in all catalysts (Figure S7). The Pt 4f core level XPS spectra of the Pt/TiO2@NC, Pt/TiO2@NC-NCNTs-9, Pt/TiO2@NC-NCNTs-7, and Pt/TiO2@NC-NCNTs-5 mainly exhibit two peaks, which are assigned to Pt 4f5/2 and Pt 4f7/2, respectively (a). In contrast to Pt/TiO2@NC, the Pt 4f peaks of the other three electrocatalysts expressively negative shift, ascribing to the electronic interaction between defects on NCNTs (NC) and Pt NPs. The negative shift of binding energy of the Pt 4f means that the Pt NPs can get electrons from the support, leading to a decrease in the d-band vacancy of Pt, according to the d-band center theory, the CO adsorption would be weakened as the d-band center decreases. Thus, the negative shift is facilitating the removal of the adsorbed poisoning intermediates such as COads for MOR. Obviously, the Pt 4f peaks of Pt/TiO2@NC-NCNTs-7 and Pt/TiO2@NC-NCNTs-5 were shifted positively compared with that of Pt/TiO2@NC-NCNTs-9, which can be attributed to the decreasing size of Pt NPs on the support. Owing to the fact that Pt0 in the nanocatalyst plays a fatal role in catalytic process, the concentration ratio between the metallic platinum (Pt0) and divalent platinum (Pt2+) are thoroughly considered and evaluated by the corresponding two sets of Pt 4f deconvolution. The percentage of metallic platinum (Pt0) in Pt/TiO2@NC-NCNTs-7 is 76%, presenting the highest level of Pt0 in the nanocatalyst (68% for Pt/TiO2@NC, 70% for Pt/TiO2@NC-NCNTs-9, 72% for Pt/TiO2@NC-NCNTs-5). The higher content of Pt0 in the nanocatalyst usually represent higher catalytic performance. The high-resolution N 1s XPS spectrum of Pt/TiO2@NC and Pt/TiO2@NC-NCNTs-X (b) can be divided into three peaks, which are corresponding to the representative peaks of pyridinic N (398.1 eV), pyrrolic N (399.5 eV), and graphitic N (401.1 eV). The excellent catalytic activities are mainly attributed to electroneutrality break and electron transfer induced by N doping (especially pyridinic-N), which alter the charge and spin distribution in the carbon materials. Compared with Pt/TiO2@NC, the negative shift of pyridinic N in Pt/TiO2@NC-NCNTs-9, Pt/TiO2@NC-NCNTs-7, and Pt/TiO2@NC-NCNTs-5 is attributed to strong metal-support interaction and electron transfer. The two peaks located at 464.5 and 458.8 eV in Ti 2p XPS spectra (c) can be associated to the Ti 2p1/2 and Ti 2p3/2 spectra of the Ti4+ oxidation state in TiO2 and a negative shift of Ti 2p ascribe that Ti4+ is partially reduced into Ti3+. The deconvoluted XPS spectra for O 1s (Figure S5) display three types of oxygen species, corresponding to Ti-O-Ti, Ti-OH, and adsorb water molecules. As shown in d, the high-resolution C 1s spectra can be decomposed into four peaks centered at 284.6 eV (sp2-sp2 C), 285.5 eV (N-sp2 C), 286.2 eV (N-sp3 C), and 288.6 eV (π-π*).

cln_elements.content: The ORR activity of the Pt/TiO2@NC-NCNTs-7 catalyst is evaluated through cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurement. A sharp cathodic peak centered at ∼0.86 V can be obviously noticed with the electrolyte saturated with O2 (a) and its location is more positive than that of commercial Pt/C (0.80 V, Figure S11), which clearly demonstrates that the ORR catalytic activity of Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 is more outstanding than Pt/C. Furthermore, Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 exhibits onset potential E onset (1.01 V) and half-wave potential E 1/2 (0.86 V, b), which are much more positive than that of commercial Pt/C (E onset = 0.96 V and E 1/2 = 0.82 V). The reaction kinetics of ORR are analyzed by Tafel plots (c). The Tafel slope of Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 (70 mV dec–1) is much smaller than that of Pt/C (77 mV dec–1), further confirming the unique (TiO2)7–Co3@NC–NCNTs support in promoting the reaction kinetics of Pt. LSV curves of Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 (d) are also collected by the rotating disk electrode setup from 400 to 2500 rpm and its corresponding Koutecky–Levich (K–L) plots are represented in e. The calculated K–L plots show nearly parallel fitting lines, indicating first-order reaction kinetics associated with the O2 concentration and a potential-independent electron transfer rate. The stability of the Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 was measured from the LSV curves initially and after 5000 cycles (f). The decrease in half-wave potential is only 4 mV signifying superior stability of the catalyst. The electrochemical tests clearly indicate that the Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 can be used as a superior bifunctional catalyst for both MOR and ORR. The extraordinary performance of the bifunctional fuel cell electrocatalyst (Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7) can be reasonably understood by the following facts. (1) Proper introduction of Co in MOFs produces both more defects and high graphitization in N-doped carbon, which not only endows the nanocatalyst with an excellent charge/electron transport ability but also provides a large amount of active sites to Pt NP deposition, further improving stability and catalytic activity in the electrochemical process. (2) High corrosion resistance and rich hydroxyl groups enable TiO2 to avoid poisoning by CO intermediates and retain the structural integrity of the whole catalysts under harsh electrochemical conditions. In a word, the catalyst of Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 has moderate defect sites, the highest content of pyridinic-N and Pt0, so the Pt/TiO2@NC–NCNTs-7 exhibits superior catalytic activity toward to MOR and ORR.

metadata.title:
Spindle-Like MOF Derived TiO2@NC–NCNTs
Composite with Modulating Defect Site and Graphitization Nanoconfined
Pt NPs as Superior Bifunctional Fuel Cell Electrocatalysts
